comments: This was detected in an informal usability test for composite cheatsheets. A user who does not realize that the buttons in the cheatsheet for "Click to Start" and "Click to Begin" need to be pressed can nonetheless view the description of each step and work through the manual steps of the cheatsheet. The downside of this is that click to perform buttons do not get activated and the composite cheatsheet does not know when a cheatsheet task has been performed.

screenshot (see comment)

I checked to see what subitems would look like, and with all the text it can look quite disorienting with many short subitems. I'm wondering if this should apply to subitems or not... (see screenshot for before and after)

Dejan, any thoughts?

Yes, this seems a bit much.

Assuming that all these links have tooltips that duplicate these labels, I would not use them this deep.

I think the original problem was that it was easy to miss the 'start' button in the intro step. I kind of like the other buttons as images only and don't think they need text.

Another thing that I have always thought of as being strange about the buttons on cheat sheets is that the skip and complete buttons stay around after they have been pressed. Since these buttons don't appear until the item becomes current perhaps they should disappear when they are no longer needed. This is most obvious with subitems but applies to items also.
I agree this is confusing.. it's not clear what's going to happen if I click on them. Feel free to open a separate bug on this one..
